official-title.#text:
To require the Transportation Security Administration to conform to existing Federal law and
			 regulations regarding criminal investigator positions, and for other
			 purposes.

cosponsor.#tail: )  (all by request): introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: TSA Office of Inspection Accountability Act of 2014
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: TSA Office of Inspection Accountability Act of 2014

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: makes the following findings:

text.#text:
Consistent with Federal law and regulations, for law enforcement officers to qualify for premium
			 pay as criminal investigators, the officers must, in general, spend on
			 average at least 50 percent of their time investigating, apprehending, or
			 detaining individuals suspected or convicted of offenses against the
			 criminal laws of the United States.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Inspector General of the Department of Homeland Security

) does not ensure that its
			 cadre of criminal investigators in the Office of Inspection are meeting
			 this requirement, even though they are considered law enforcement officers
			 under
policy and receive premium pay.

criminal investigators in the Office of Inspection primarily monitor the results of
			 criminal investigations conducted by other agencies, investigate
			 administrative cases of

employee misconduct, and carry out
			 inspections, covert tests, and internal reviews, which the

asserts
			 could be performed by employees other than criminal investigators at a
			 lower cost.

criminal investigators in the Office of
			 Inspection who are incorrectly classified as such will cost the taxpayer
			 as much as $17,000,000 over 5 years if

fails to make any changes to
			 the number of criminal investigators in the Office of Inspection,

This may be a conservative estimate, as it accounts for the cost of Law Enforcement Availability
			 Pay, but not the costs of law enforcement training, statutory early
			 retirement benefits, police vehicles, and weapons.
